segments.pli: Saṃyutta Nikāya 4
segments.en: Linked Discourses 4

segments.pli: 3. Tatiyavagga
segments.en: 3. Māra

segments.pli: 21. Sambahulasutta
segments.en: 21. Several

segments.pli: Evaṃ me sutaṃ—
segments.en: So I have heard.

segments.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati silāvatiyaṃ.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans near Silāvatī.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā bhikkhū bhagavato avidūre appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharanti.
segments.en: Now at that time several mendicants were meditating not far from the Buddha, diligent, keen, and resolute.

segments.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā brāhmaṇavaṇṇaṃ abhinimminitvā mahantena jaṭaṇḍuvena ajinakkhipanivattho jiṇṇo gopānasivaṅko ghurughurupassāsī udumbaradaṇḍaṃ gahetvā yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te bhikkhū etadavoca:
segments.en: Then Māra the Wicked manifested in the form of a brahmin with a large matted dreadlock, wearing an antelope hide. He was old, bent double, wheezing, and held a staff made of cluster fig tree wood. He went up to those mendicants and said,

segments.pli: “daharā bhavanto pabbajitā susū kāḷakesā bhadrena yobbanena samannāgatā paṭhamena vayasā anikkīḷitāvino kāmesu.
segments.en: “You’ve gone forth while young, reverends. You’re black-haired, blessed with youth, in the prime of life, and you’ve never flirted with sensual pleasures.

segments.pli: Bhuñjantu bhavanto mānusake kāme.
segments.en: Enjoy human sensual pleasures.

segments.pli: Mā sandiṭṭhikaṃ hitvā kālikaṃ anudhāvitthā”ti.
segments.en: Don’t give up what is visible in the present to chase after what takes effect over time.”

segments.pli: “Na kho mayaṃ, brāhmaṇa, sandiṭṭhikaṃ hitvā kālikaṃ anudhāvāma.
segments.en: “Brahmin, that’s not what we’re doing.

segments.pli: Kālikañca kho mayaṃ, brāhmaṇa, hitvā sandiṭṭhikaṃ anudhāvāma.
segments.en: We’re giving up what takes effect over time to chase after what is visible in the present.

segments.pli: Kālikā hi, brāhmaṇa, kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo.
segments.en: For the Buddha says that sensual pleasures take effect over time; they give much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.

segments.pli: Sandiṭṭhiko ayaṃ dhammo akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī”ti.
segments.en: But this teaching is visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.”

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte, māro pāpimā sīsaṃ okampetvā jivhaṃ nillāletvā tivisākhaṃ nalāṭe nalāṭikaṃ vuṭṭhāpetvā daṇḍamolubbha pakkāmi.
segments.en: When they had spoken, Māra the Wicked shook his head, waggled his tongue, raised his eyebrows until his brow puckered in three furrows, and departed leaning on his staff.

segments.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
segments.en: Then those senior mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. The Buddha said,

segments.pli: “idha mayaṃ, bhante, bhagavato avidūre appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharāma.
Atha kho, bhante, aññataro brāhmaṇo mahantena jaṭaṇḍuvena ajinakkhipanivattho jiṇṇo gopānasivaṅko ghurughurupassāsī udumbaradaṇḍaṃ gahetvā yena mayaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā amhe etadavoca:
‘daharā bhavanto pabbajitā susū kāḷakesā bhadrena yobbanena samannāgatā paṭhamena vayasā anikkīḷitāvino kāmesu.
Bhuñjantu bhavanto mānusake kāme.
Mā sandiṭṭhikaṃ hitvā kālikaṃ anudhāvitthā’ti.
Evaṃ vutte, mayaṃ, bhante, taṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavocumha:
‘na kho mayaṃ, brāhmaṇa, sandiṭṭhikaṃ hitvā kālikaṃ anudhāvāma.
Kālikañca kho mayaṃ, brāhmaṇa, hitvā sandiṭṭhikaṃ anudhāvāma.
Kālikā hi, brāhmaṇa, kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo.
Sandiṭṭhiko ayaṃ dhammo akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī’ti.
Evaṃ vutte, bhante, so brāhmaṇo sīsaṃ okampetvā jivhaṃ nillāletvā tivisākhaṃ nalāṭe nalāṭikaṃ vuṭṭhāpetvā daṇḍamolubbha pakkanto”ti.
“Neso, bhikkhave, brāhmaṇo.
segments.en: “Mendicants, that was no brahmin.

segments.pli: Māro eso pāpimā tumhākaṃ vicakkhukammāya āgato”ti.
segments.en: That was Māra the Wicked who came to pull the wool over your eyes!”

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
segments.en: Then, knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha recited this verse:

segments.pli: “Yo dukkhamaddakkhi yatonidānaṃ,
segments.en: “When a person has seen where suffering comes from

segments.pli: Kāmesu so jantu kathaṃ nameyya;
segments.en: how could they incline towards sensual pleasures?

segments.pli: Upadhiṃ viditvā saṅgoti loke,
segments.en: Realizing that attachment is a tie in the world,

segments.pli: Tasseva jantu vinayāya sikkhe”ti.
segments.en: a person would train to remove it.”

suttaplex.blurb: Māra approaches some young mendicants as an old brahmin, and tries to tempt them with talk of the pleasures of youth.
